awd_titl_txt: Sonified Interactive Simulations for Accessible Middle School STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
Students with disabilities often have fewer opportunities for experiential learning, an important component of quality STEM education.  Computer based simulations in science can provide valuable opportunities for these students to experience and manipulate natural phenomena related to critical STEM ideas.  However, existing simulations remain largely inaccessible to students with visual impairments in particular.  Recent advances in technology related to sonification use with simulations can make it possible for these students to have a more complete and authentic experience. Sonification is the use of non-speech sounds, such as musical tones, to represent visual information including data.  Such sounds can be manipulated temporally and spatially and can also vary by amplitude and frequency to convey information that is more traditionally displayed visually.  

Researchers will iteratively develop five middle school physical science simulations to include sonifications aimed at enhancing accessibility for all learners, but particularly for those with visual impairments.  Data collection activities will include focus groups and interviews with students and teachers focused on engagement. The end products of this project will include sonified simulations, professional development resources, design guidelines and exemplars, and publications.   

The Discovery Research PreK-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
Digital interactive learning tools are widely used to support STEM learning. Interactive simulations are digital learning tools that allow students to change parameters of an underlying mathematical or physical model and experience the outcome of those changes, allowing learners to actively engage in sensemaking of STEM concepts. By actively changing parameters and experiencing the outcomes, interactive simulations are particularly effective for supporting students to engage in science practices such as developing explanations, models, and theories of physical phenomena through the process of experimentation. 

In this project, we utilized a design-based research approach to advance understanding of the design, use, and implementation of sonification, which is a type of auditory display, to augment the visual display of interactive simulations. In so doing, we aimed to enhance the accessibility of interactive simulations for learners with disabilities and to develop the necessary foundational knowledge for the STEM education field to advance the use of sonification to support learning of STEM concepts for all learners. 

This project enabled a new collaboration between two research groups to develop and study sonified interactive simulations. The PhET Interactive Simulations project (University of Colorado Boulder) develops and researches award-winning interactive STEM simulations used around the world. The Sonification Lab (Georgia Tech) is an international leader in sonification research and design. Together, the project team collaborated to research and develop interactive simulations made more accessible to learners with diverse needs, including learners with visual impairments, through auditory display. Research included interviews with individual learners (with and without sensory disabilities), implementation of activities utilizing sonified simulations within formal and informal learning environments inclusive of learners with and without disabilities, and surveys of teachers and students about their perceptual and conceptual understanding of the sonified simulations and their perceptions of use and learning with the sonified simulations. 

Outcomes included 13 sonified physics, chemistry, and mathematics simulations (collectively run over 18 million times in 2021). Each simulation is openly licensed, accessible to teachers, students, and parents for free from the widely used PhET Interactive Simulations website and also utilized by third-party STEM education publishing, assessment, and educational technology organizations, and each comes with a brief "Sound Features" video describing the sonifications and sharing teacher tips on pedagogical strategies specific to the sonifications in each simulation. In the process of designing, developing, and investigating the use of the sonified simulations, we published numerous papers sharing findings on how students with diverse needs, including learners who are blind or have significant visual impairments and learners with intellectual and developmental disabilities, make use of the sonifications in the simulations to support their understanding of STEM concepts. We also shared design guidelines and practices that result in highly effective sonifications, addressing questions central in the auditory display field. These central questions include: 1) What qualities of sonification sounds map to, cue, and contextualize the STEM concepts within a simulation, 2) What factors influence the interpretation and navigation of simulations with multiple dynamic sonifications, 3) How to create and implement sounds for sonifications that are aesthetically pleasing, effective for learning, and utilize standard Web technologies (i.e., Web Audio), 4) How do students engage with, use, and learn from sonified simulations?, and 5) How do teachers perceive sonified simulations and their feasibility for use for STEM learners?.

The resulting sonified simulations, professional development materials, research findings, design guidelines, exemplars, and software are disseminated through the project teams' extensive partner networks, high-traffic education resource websites, third-party educational resources, a free online short course on designing sonification for interactive learning resources (available through the Coursera platform), conference presentations across STEM education, human-computer interaction, and accessible technology communities, conference proceedings papers, journal publications, and professional organizations.

Throughout the project, we worked directly with learners with diverse needs. We also involved over a dozen undergraduate and graduate students in the research, exposing them to research involving STEM education materials and learners with disabilities. We also participated in and seeded the creation of new communities of people interested in sonification, and the use of sonification and auditory display to support STEM learning, and learning for people with disabilities. The project findings immediately impacted the design and development of new and existing PhET sims, and provide guidelines, technical infrastructure, and exemplars to guide and support the broader STEM development community in creation and enhancement of accessible STEM resources.These outcomes will affect a broad and diverse student population. It is a well-known phenomenon that enhancements made to accommodate learners with disabilities enable more effective learning for all students. This is referred to as the "curb cut advantage." Sidewalk curbs are cut to accommodate people with wheelchairs, but are used by people with strollers, bicycles, wheeled luggage, etc.; The sonified simulations developed in this project, and the knowledge developed and shared for application to new interactive contexts, can benefit all learners.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2021
Modified by: Emily B Moore

Images (1 of )
  • List of sonified PhET simulations that resulted from this grant, available from http://phet.colorado.edu. List includes: Balloons and Static Electricity, Faraday's Law, Fourier: Making Waves, Friction, Gravity Force Lab, Gravity Force Lab: Basics, John Travoltage, and Molarity.
    PhET Interactive Simulations Project, University of Colorado Boulder
    Copyrighted
    Emily B Moore
    Outcomes: List of Sonified PhET Simulations (1-8 of 13 published)
  • List of sonified PhET simulations that resulted from this grant, available from http://phet.colorado.edu. List includes: Molecules and Light, Ohm's Law, Ratio and Proportion, Resistance in a Wire, and Waves: Intro. Also notes the 13 published sims were run over 18 million times in 2021.
    PhET Interactive Simulations Project, University of Colorado Boulder
    Copyrighted
    Emily B Moore
    Outcomes: List of Sonified PhET Simulations (9-13 of 13 published)
  • List of technology & media products resulting from this grant beyond the sonified PhET simulations. These include: Tambo and Skiffle Github repositories, PhET Accessibility webpage (http://phet.colorado.edu/en/accessibility), Sound Features videos, and Sound & Sonification Design Coursera MOOC.
    PhET Interactive Simulations Project, University of Colorado Boulder
    Copyrighted
    Emily B Moore
    Outcomes: Other technology and media products
  • List of six publications categorized by the topic "Design and Evaluation of Sonified Simulations". These include: Tomlinson, et al. (2021); Tomlinson, et al. (2020); Tomlinson et al. (2019); Winters et al. (2019); Tomlinson, et al. (2018); and Tomlinson, et al. (2018, Oct).
    PhET Interactive Simulations, University of Colorado Boulder
    Copyrighted
    Emily B Moore
    Outcomes: Publications List (Topic: Design and Evaluation of Sonified Simulations)
  • List of five publications categorized by the topic "Inclusive Design with Sonified Simulations". These include: Tennison, et al. (2017); Winters, et al. (2020, Oct); Smith & Moore (2020); Moore & Perkins (2018); Perkins & Moore (2017).
    PhET Interactive Simulations, University of Colorado Boulder.
    Copyrighted
    Emily B Moore
    Outcomes: Publications List (Topic: Inclusive Design with Sonified Simulations)
  • List of two publications categorized by the topic "Educator Perceptions of Sonified Simulations". These include: Fiedler, et al. (2021) (ICAD) and Fiedler, et al. (2021) (PERC). Also, one publications categorized by the topic "Sonified Simulations for Informal Learning": Fiedler, et al. (2019).
    PhET Interactive Simulations, University of Colorado Boulder
    Copyrighted
    Emily B Moore
    Outcomes: Publications List (Topic: Educator Perceptions of Sonified Sims & Sonified Sims in Informal Learning)
